item.title: This is why we have a taxpayer funded news gathering organisation in the ABC
item.dc:creator: Michael Smith

item.title: My mate Dave just got this email from me because I am an expert on being an ex-cop and I'm sick of the lies from the Liberals
item.description: You might want to read this post first. Dear Dave, As someone who has been a policeman and a soldier for a combined 13 years, I’m sick of the misinformation campaign being run by the Liberal Party and sections of the media about law and order. Let’s have a debate...
item.content:encoded:
You might want to read this post first.

 

Dear Dave,

As someone who has been a policeman and a soldier for a combined 13 years, I’m sick of the misinformation campaign being run by the Liberal Party and sections of the media about law and order.

Let’s have a debate on law and order, for sure, but let’s make sure we stick to the facts.

This morning it’s continued with a beat-up in the tabloid press about someone being shot and killed, totally misrepresenting the real picture about how much worse things are elsewhere.

The fact is Australian criminals shoot and kill dramatically fewer people than the daily shot-and-killed tally for every single major troubled community.

Our current daily shot-and-killed is a piddling fraction of a percent of the whole population – compared to hundreds who get shot and killed daily in Somalia and Syria.

We should make a choice to assign taxpayer money to meeting our interest payments – rather than paying for police who can’t be everywhere anyway.   And as you can see on the graph below, those countries with lots of armed people have much worse daily death rates from shooting than we do anyway.



Our daily shot-and-killed rate is so low that we could do with much less spending on law and order right now as proven in the graph.   The statistics of being shot-and-killed on any given day are the envy of the Middle East and South Central LA.

Listening to the Liberal Party you would think that police action and locking up crooks made the streets safe – when Australia is already miles ahead of Afghanistan, Somalia, Syria and some suburbs of Washington DC.

It’s fair to say that if the Liberal Party had their way we’d have armed uniformed police patrolling streets unnecessarily doing nothing and wasting their time – and that costs money that could be spent on meeting our interest payments.

 

Michael Smith

Former everything
item.dc:creator: Michael Smith

item.title: Jon Faine takes on the ABC bosses and loses.
item.description: Jon Faine is required to toe the ABC line. Where's the fire in the belly Jon? Jon Faine said he wasn't happy with ABC management apologising for his behaviour in his interviews with me and Mark Baker of The Age on 23 November last year. He said he'd take it...
item.content:encoded:
Jon Faine is required to toe the ABC line.

Where's the fire in the belly Jon?

Jon Faine said he wasn't happy with ABC management apologising for his behaviour in his interviews with me and Mark Baker of The Age on 23 November last year.  He said he'd take it further.

This is from The Australian of 1 February this year:

The interview included The Age newspaper's editor-at-large, Mark Baker, and was characterised by Faine's hectoring of Smith and his assertion that he "give it his best shot".

Faine was both defiant and unapologetic yesterday and vowed to fight the decision.

"There are very important issues at stake," he said. "As far as I'm concerned I'm not satisfied with the findings and will pursue the matter further.

"I'm unhappy with the finding, I don't think its right and will see where I can take it."

Jon, if the management won't back you, resign and you get to take your principles and dignity with you. Stay and you and management go halves in each other's.

I've done the resign-over-principle thing and it feels great.   If more people did it, we'd have less spin, less bulltish, less compromised principles and fewer meetings.

Here's the latest ABC corresondence about Jon Faine with one of our readers.

Our reader wrote on 5 February to the ABC.

 Dear ABC

Thankyou for your reply.

Sadly, since the unacceptable behaviour of Mr.Faine and his conduct during this interview, I have read that he will not accept the decision of the umpire?

Clearly, that is quite unacceptable.

Some people are claiming that Mr.Faine knew Ms.Gillard personally? From my memory, this was not disclosed at the time of the interview, and if it's true, then I think that it should have been.

Mr.Faine appears to be making no attempt to apologise to the two men who he treated so poorly? Why is the ABC allowing this type of behaviour to go unchecked? What is the point of complaining, and the ABC finding that he breached policy, if they aren't going to do anything about it?

I believe that the ABC should insist that he apologises immediately.
 
I also think that given the fact that it is reported elsewhere that the Victorian Police Fraud Squad may apparently be conducting an extensive investigation into allegations sent to them regarding our Prime Minister, that the ABC owes the Australian public a proper and fair interview pertaining to these matters?

Does the ABC have a journalist who would be capable of allowing Mr.Smith to explain the complex issues regarding the AWU Fraud?

When might the ABC allow this issue to be aired in a sensible manner?

At this point in time in appears that the ABC is withholdng what seems like very important information, from the people of Australia?

Why would the ABC do that?

 

The ABC's investigation people have just written back to our correspondent.

 

Thank you for your email further email.

As explained in my initial response, ABC Radio management has apologised to complainants and Jon Faine has been reminded of his obligation to gather and present news and information content with due impartiality.  A summary of the Audience and Consumer Affairs finding has been published on the ABC Audience and Consumer Affairs website at:  http://about.abc.net.au/talk-to-the-abc/feedback-and-enquiries/upheld-complaints/   Further, the matter has been reported to the ABC Board.  This action is in keeping with our normal processes.

Audience and Consumer Affairs conducted an independent investigation into this matter and the finding was accepted by ABC Radio management.  Any further action is an internal and confidential matter for ABC Radio.

Please be assured that your further comments are noted.  Should you remain dissatisfied with this response,  you may be able to pursue your concerns with the Australian Communications and Media Authority,http://www.acma.gov.au

 
Yours sincerely,
 
Denise Musto
Investigations Manager
Audience and Consumer Affairs
item.dc:creator: Michael Smith

item.title: How to get money?
item.description: I have never had so exquisite an understanding of how you get money as now. I get money when people get value from this website. In my life I've observed two main attitudes about how you get money. One is make something, sell something, do something for someone - create...
item.content:encoded:
I have never had so exquisite an understanding of how you get money as now.

I get money when people get value from this website.

In my life I've observed two main attitudes about how you get money.

One is make something, sell something, do something for someone - create value - and get paid.

The other is fill out an indent.

This is an indent form from an Indian University.


See how you've got to fill it out, get it signed, then you get your stuff.

Stephen Conroy has the same view about say money for an NBN.

The Gillard Government is serenely untroubled by worries like how you get money.   The Government's attitude to money and debt is personified in the continuing fact of Wayne Swan and his ilk.

Strangely, we were once a whole country of people who knew that money represented hours of work and value.   Not now, and the indent-mindset is growing

People act strangely once they get the indent thing.   I watched it in my extended family when you could indent for $1600 for ceiling insulation then go halves with a carpet-bagger whose signature was needed on the form.

The reaction to the first hit is so powerful that addiction sets in immediately.   And it grows.

We have to start to run that attitude out of our community.   If we don't manage that process, then we'll go Greek or Cypriot one day and things might get nasty on the streets.

Don't cop money-indenters running the show.   When you stop creating value, it's surprising how quickly the value you've stored runs out.  

We have to focus on making money - and that needs some real work right now.
item.dc:creator: Michael Smith
